facts.text: Vijay Pratap Singh, a minor by his next friend Pandit Brij Mohan Misir, filed a petition in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Faizabad for leave to sue in forma pauperis.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-Vijay Pratap Singh hereinafter called the plaintiff  a minor-by his next friend Pandit Brij Mohan Misir filed a petition in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Faizabad for leave to sue in forma pauperis for declaration of title to the Ajodhya Raj and accretions thereto and for possession and mesne profits for three years prior to the suit.

facts.text: The petition sought declaration of title to the Ajodhya Raj and accretions thereto, possession and mesne profits for three years prior to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Vijay Pratap Singh hereinafter called the plaintiff  a minor-by his next friend Pandit Brij Mohan Misir filed a petition in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Faizabad for leave to sue in forma pauperis for declaration of title to the Ajodhya Raj and accretions thereto and for possession and mesne profits for three years prior to the suit.

facts.text: The Subordinate Judge rejected the petition because it disclosed no cause of action.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was rejected by the Subordinate Judge because, in his view, it disclosed numbercause of action.

facts.text: Ramjiwan Misir, father of the plaintiff and impleaded as second defendant, applied to be transposed as a petitioner, which was rejected by the Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: An application by Ramjiwan Misir father of the plaintiff who was impleaded as the second defendant, to be transposed as a petitioner was also rejected by the Subordinate Judge.

facts.text: Maharaja Sir Man Singh, holder of the Ajodhya Raj, was a Taluqdar in lists I, II and V of the Oudh states set I of 1869, died in 1870.

anchor.surface_text: The case set up by the plaintiff in his petition was briefly this. Maharaja Sir Man Singh holder of the Ajodhya Raj was a Taluqdar in lists I, II and V of the Oudh states set I of 1869. He died in 1870

facts.text: The Raj devolved upon his daughter's son Maharaja Pratap Narain Singh, who died on November 9, 1906.

anchor.surface_text: and the Raj devolved upon his daughters son Maharaja Pratap Narain Singh, who died on November 9, 1906, leaving him surviving two widows Suraj Kumari and Jagdamba Devi and numberlineal descendant.

facts.text: Maharaja Pratap Narain Singh left surviving two widows: Suraj Kumari and Jagdamba Devi, and no lineal descendant.

anchor.surface_text: who died on November 9, 1906, leaving him surviving two widows Suraj Kumari and Jagdamba Devi and numberlineal descendant.

facts.text: A will alleged to be executed by Maharaja Pratap Narain Singh on July 20, 1891, was set up but claimed void due to undue influence, coercion and fraud.

anchor.surface_text: and on her death in 1927 upon Maharani Jugdamba Devi, and on the death of the latter on June 18, 1928 upon Ganga Dutt Misir, grand father of the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: and on the death of the latter on June 18, 1928 upon Ganga Dutt Misir, grand father of the plaintiff Ganga Dutt Misir died in 1942

facts.text: Raj in wrongful possession of first defendant Dukh Haran Singh.

anchor.surface_text: for the reasons set out in the partition, and the Raj was in the wrongful possession of the first defendant Dukh Haran Singh.

facts.text: Plaintiff's father Ramjiwan Misir detained and confined by first defendant, unable to join petition.

facts.text: Ramjiwan applied on April 21, 1951 to be transposed as petitioner, claiming previous statement procured by coercion.

anchor.surface_text: but by an application dated April 21, 1951, prayed that he be transposed as a petitioner submitting that his previous statement was procured by companyrcion and companytained averments which were untrue.

facts.text: Ramjiwan directed to pay court fee within ten days, failed to pay.

facts.text: Ramjiwan reapplied on July 23, 1951 for transposition.

anchor.surface_text: Ramjiwan did number pay the companyrt fee as directed but on July 23, 1951, he again applied for being transposed as a petitioner

facts.text: Subordinate Judge rejected both petitions for no cause of action.

anchor.surface_text: Holding that it did number disclose a cause of action the Subordinate Judge rejected the petition of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Plaintiff preferred Revision No. 881 of 1952, Ramjiwan Revision No. 882 of 1952 to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the two orders passed by the subordinate Judge the plaintiff preferred Revision Application No. 881 of 1952 and Ram Jiwan preferred Revision Petition 882 of 1952.

facts.text: High Court rejected plaintiff's revision holding estate devolved on Ramjiwan alone per rule of impartibility on Ganga Dutt's death in 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected the petition of the plaintiff holding that on the death of Ganga Dutt in 1942 the estate would devolve upon Ram Jiwan Misir alone according to the rule of impartibility which governed the devolution of the estate.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal against High Court orders.

facts.text: Litigation instituted nearly twelve years ago (around 1950).

facts.text: Petition filed in July 1950 for leave to sue in forma pauperis.

facts.text: Supreme Court special leave granted in March 1957.

Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 2,1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Revision Nos. 881 and 882 of 1952.
They have with special leave appealed to this Court against the orders passed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 5 provides The Court shall reject an application for permission to sue as a pauper-  a  where it is number framed and presented in the manner prescribed by rules 2 and 3, or  b  where the applicant is number a pauper, or  c  where he has, within two months next before the presentation of the application, disposed of any property fraudulently or in order to be able to apply for permission to sue as a pauper, or  d  where his allegations do number show a cause of action, or  e  where he has entered into any agreement with reference to the subject matter of the proposed suit under which any other person has obtained an interest in such subject matter.

The procedure under Order XXXIII CPC for pauper applications grounds the holding that a suit commences upon presentation of the application and that O.1 r.10 applies.
Order XXXIII CPC prescribes rejection grounds under r.5 for pauper petitions, which encompasses assessment of whether the petition discloses a cause of action.
Order XXXIII CPC procedure for institution of pauper suits via petitions addresses questions on procedural aspects like transposing parties in such petitions.
Order XXXIII CPC prescribes procedure for institution of suits by paupers starting with presentation of application, directly addressing when the suit commences.
Order 33 Rule 5 CPC provides basis for holding on prima facie disclosure
Rule on prima facie cause of action without merits trial directly addresses the issue
Concept c5 on O1 r.10 applying to pauper petitions for transposition of parties supports holding h2 permitting its use for that purpose.
Concept c5 articulates that O1 r.10 CPC applies to pauper petitions because suit commences upon presentation, supporting holding h3 on the same principle.
